title: Time System Template
description: Defines how time is measured: hours, days, weeks, months, years, and calendar structure. Keep minutes and hours Earth-like; change weeks, months, and year length instead. Reveal differences through character dialogue, not exposition.
source_chapter: V2 Ch10 -- Creating Time and History

hours_per_day.description: Hours in a day (recommend close to 24)

days_per_week.description: Days in a week (recommend 6 or 8 to stay close to Earth)

day_names.description: Day names and their origins (celestial bodies, gods, schools of magic, etc.)

month_names.description: Month names -- avoid seasonal associations (they fail across hemispheres)

calendar_anchor_event.description: What year zero represents (birth of magic, cataclysm, mass exodus)

year_start.description: What event starts the new year (should be unrelated to weather/seasons)

named_ages.description: Named historical ages (typically thousands of years)

current_age.description: The current age (may lack a name)

associated_concept.description: Element, season, deity, or concept this week is associated with

week_names.description: Named weeks within a month (e.g., Fireweek, Waterweek -- based on elements, seasons, or other groupings)

internal_calendars.description: Sovereign power-specific calendars -- each power may have its own year-one event (founding, dynasty, cataclysm)

hemisphere_naming_issues.description: Avoid seasonal month/week names that only apply to one hemisphere -- use event-based names instead

how_differences_revealed.description: How time differences are communicated to the audience (dialogue, not exposition)

x-cross-references.planet-profile: Day and year length are determined by the planet's properties
x-cross-references.world-history-timeline: Ages and calendar are used in the history timeline
